body: :+1: for following [Android recommendations](https://developer.android.com/reference/android/app/Activity.html). Same can be done for the `RadioButton`s and the `EditText`.

Extra points for commenting your code :+1:  You used **descriptive blocks**. There are a few other types of comments that will come in handy and you can find them in [this article](http://www.hongkiat.com/blog/source-code-comment-styling-tips/).

PLease remove this **else** statement from this method and the one below. What happens if you add 0 to a number? Nothing. This case has no purpose. Please remove it and avoid cluttering code with statements that have no value.

What if the input is "8 mile"? Or "8 Mile "? There are some methods for [string manipulation](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/lang/String.html) in Java that might come in handy. For example `toLowerCase()` which would change upper case letters to lower case letters. Give it a try, see how it works!

Which method do you need for "8 Mile "? :stuck_out_tongue_winking_eye:

Avoid using hardcoded strings, rather use **string resources**. The [official Android documentation](https://developer.android.com/guide/topics/resources/string-resource.html) exemplifies how to bind **string resources** in Java code. Pay extra attention to the **Formatting strings** section :wink: It will show you how to create strings with dynamic values.
This is the place where you can add the **if/else statement** :smile:

Global int variables are by default set to 0, thus there is no need to do it yourself. As a second note, in Android class variables are called member variables and they start with a small **m**. Your variable would translate to `mScore`.
Blank lines are used to delimit blocks of code. Please remove all blank lines in this code. Only leave those that really really make sense as code block separators.
